courses.subject: GLEF
courses.title: International Monetary Systems

meetings.location: Lee Shau Kee Archi Bldg G02
Lee Shau Kee Archi Bldg G02
Lee Shau Kee Archi Bldg G02
Lee Shau Kee Archi Bldg G02

courses.description: This course studies the evolution and development of international monetary and exchange rate systems. Major monetary regimes and institutions, such as international gold standard, Great Depression of the 1930s, post-World War II Bretton Woods system and the International Monetary Fund (IMF), as well as post-1973 floating exchange rate system, are introduced. Important issues on macroeconomic policy goals of internal and external balance and international policy coordination are addressed. In addition, selected topics, including global imbalance and financial crisis, are covered.
courses.learning_outcomes:
1. To understand international monetary and exchange rate systems and institutions.
2. To understand macroeconomic policy goals of internal and external balance and issues on international policy coordination.
courses.course_syllabus:
1. International gold standard (1870-1914)
2. The Great Depression of 1930s
3. The fixed exchange rate system under the Bretton Woods agreement (1946-1973) and the IMF
4. The floating exchange rate system (1973-present)
5. International policy coordination
courses.feedback_evaluation:
Course and teaching evaluation at end of course
Informal feedback channels throughout the course (face-to-face, email, WebCT)
Departmental Retreat
Programme Review
courses.required_readings: Solomon, R., 1982, The International Monetary System, 1945-1981. New York: Harper & Row, 1982.
courses.recommended_readings: Obstfeld, M. and A. M. Taylor, 2004, Global Capital Markets: Integration, Crisis and Growth. Cambridge, U.K.: Cambridge University Press.

courses.subject: GLEF
courses.title: Global and Regional Economic Integration
courses.description: From economic, political and social perspectives, this course discusses costs and benefits as well as opportunities and challenges of economic integration and cooperation. The issues on multilateral negotiations, trade liberalization and globalization are examined. Major international trade and monetary organizations, such as General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade (GATT), World Trade Organization (WTO), International Monetary Fund (IMF) and the World Bank, are introduced. Major developments on global and regional economic integration, including the North American Free Trade Agreement (NAFTA), the European Union, Free Trade Agreements (FTAs) in Asia such as the ASEAN FTA (AFTA), the China-ASEAN FTA (CAFTA), and FTAs in South America are introduced.
courses.learning_outcomes:
1) To understand the economic theory on costs and benefits of economic integration and cooperation
2) To discuss opportunities and challenges of economic integration and cooperation
3) To understand major international trade and monetary institutions and organizations
4) To understand the historical stages and developments of regional economic integration and cooperation
courses.course_syllabus:
1) The costs and benefits of economic integration and cooperation
2) The opportunities and challenges of economic integration and cooperation
3) Multilateral negotiations, trade liberalization, and globalization
4) Design and sustainability of global and regional integration
5) International trade and monetary institutions and organizations
6) Cases for global and regional economic integration
courses.feedback_evaluation:
Course and teaching evaluation at end of course
Informal feedback channels throughout the course (face-to-face, email, WebCT)
Departmental retreat
Programme review
courses.required_readings: Barro, R. J. and J. W. Lee, 2011, Costs and Benefits of Economic Integration in Asia, Oxford University Press.
courses.recommended_readings: Baldwin, R. E., 1997, “The Causes of Regionalism,” World Economy, 20.7, pp. 865-888.

courses.subject: GLEF
courses.title: Global Financial Markets
courses.description: This course provides an introduction to modern finance theory and its application to global financial markets. The course examines the foreign exchange market and related markets in derivatives such as foreign exchange futures, currency and interest rate swaps, and currency options, the eurocurrency market, international bond markets, and cross-border flow of equity investment.
courses.enrollment_requirement:
1. Pre-requisite(s): FINA2010 or FINA2310 or permission from the instructor
2. Not for students who have taken FINA3010
courses.course_syllabus: This course provides an introduction to modern finance theory and its application to global financial markets. The course examines the foreign exchange market and related markets in derivatives such as foreign exchange futures, currency and interest rate swaps, and currency options, the eurocurrency market, international bond markets, and cross-border flow of equity investment.
courses.feedback_evaluation: The course will employ the University’s Courses and Teaching Evaluation (CTE) as evaluation tool and reflection collected from individual student would be collated to see the effectiveness of the course in delivery of learning outcomes.
courses.recommended_readings: Bruno Solnik and Dennis McLeacey, 2009, Global Investment (Pearson)

courses.subject: GLEF
courses.title: Corporate Social Responsibility in a Globalized Economy
courses.description: This course provides an introduction to the tensions and trade-offs involved in the adoption of Corporate Social Responsibility (CSR) by a firm in a globalized economy. It will enable students to evaluate the economic and other factors involved in the adoption of CSR, the implications of implementing and embedding CSR in a corporation as well as the implications of CSR for capital markets.
courses.learning_outcomes:
1. Students will learn to understand the problems involved in implementing a CSR program and the culture change necessary to achieve a successful CSR firm strategy for companies previously concerned only with shareholder value.
2. Students will learn the implications for a firm in terms of risk and competitiveness of the adoption of a CSR agenda when other firms in its markets may not have done so.
courses.course_syllabus: This course provides an introduction to the tensions and trade-offs involved in the adoption of Corporate Social Responsibility (CSR) by a firm in a globalized economy. It will enable students to evaluate the economic and other factors involved in the adoption of CSR, the implications of implementing and embedding CSR in a corporation as well as the implications of CSR for capital markets.
courses.feedback_evaluation: The course will employ the University’s Courses and Teaching Evaluation (CTE) as evaluation tool and reflection collected from individual student would be collated to see the effectiveness of the course in delivery of learning outcomes.
courses.recommended_readings:
- Strategic Corporate Social Responsibility: Stakeholders in a Global Environment Hardcover, by William B. Werther and David B. Chandler.
- Magazines: Asiamoney, Euromoney, Finance Asia.

courses.subject: GLEF
courses.title: Issues in Global Finance
courses.description: This course introduces current issues and topics in global finance. This is a student-oriented course and students are required to research and discuss articles on related topics. This course provides an opportunity for students to integrate knowledge acquired from previous courses under the guidance of an instructor. Group-based research projects will be conducted. Weekly presentations will be held. Requirements include the writing of reports, formal term-end presentations of papers and participation in class discussions.
courses.learning_outcomes:
Students will be able to:
- discuss current developments in the international financial arena;
- understand the basics of international financial environments; and
- apply and integrate relevant concepts through written essays.
courses.feedback_evaluation: The course will employ the University’s Courses and Teaching Evaluation (CTE) as evaluation tool and reflection collected from individual student would be collated to see the effectiveness of the course in delivery of learning outcomes.

courses.subject: GLEF
courses.title: China and Global Economy
courses.description: The rise of China is the major event of the 21st century. This course starts with the impact of China’s opening and internationalization on the Chinese economy, and proceeds to examine the challenges of the rise of China to the global economic order. Topics include the impact of China on world trade and investment, the internationalization of Renminbi and its prospect as a global reserve currency, China’s bilateral and regional trade agreements, China and global energy and environmental issues, China’s impact on international bodies of economic coordination and governance (such as the Group of Twenty, the World Trade Organization, and the International Monetary Fund), and the analysis and assessment of the challenges of China to global economic, monetary, and financial governance.
courses.learning_outcomes:
1. Understand the impact of China’s liberalization on the Chinese economy
2. Understand the major issues and challenges of the impact of China’s rise on the global economy
3. Be able to intelligently discuss and evaluate the debates on theses issues
courses.course_syllabus:
1. Liberalization of China and its impact on China’s Economy
2. China’s impact on world trade and investment and on major economic partners
3. Internationalization of Renminbi and its prospect as a global reserve currency
4. China’s pursuit of bilateral and regional trading agreements
5. China’s roles in global energy and environmental issues
6. China’s impact on international bodies of economic coordination and governance
7. Evaluation of China’s challenges to global economic, monetary, and financial governance
courses.feedback_evaluation:
Course and teaching evaluation at end of course
Informal feedback channels throughout the course (face-to-face, email, WebCT)
Departmental Retreat
Programme Review
courses.required_readings:
C. Fred Bergsten et. al., 2008. China’s Rise: Challenges and Opportunities, Peterson Institute for International Economics and Center for Strategic and International Studies, Washington D.C.

C. Fred Bergsten et. al., 2006. China: The Balance Sheet – What the World Needs to Know Now About the Emerging Superpower, Public Affairs.
courses.recommended_readings:
Barry Naughton, 2007. The Chinese Economy: Transitions and Growth, The MIT Press.

John Saee ed., 2011. China and the Global Economy in the 21st Century, Taylor and Francis Asia Pacific.

courses.subject: GLEF
courses.title: International Banking and Financial Regulation
courses.description: This course gives an overview on the architecture and development of banking and financial regulation in the international context. It discusses the fundamental issues in banking regulation, the role of central banks and the international cooperation in monetary policies and financial regulations. It incorporates both normative and positive analyses of issues in banking regulation, including the cause and damage of financial crises, the function of regulatory bodies in maintaining the stability of financial system and in preventing or ameliorating financial crises, and how monetary authorities or institutions can deal with financial issues in the era of globalization. The course includes three major topics: (1) fundament issues in financial regulation and the mitigation of systemic risks; (2) the development of the financial sector and its regulation; (3) new issues and development of financial regulation under globalization.
courses.learning_outcomes:
• Understand the basic mechanism and framework of financial regulation
• Understand the rationale of financial regulation
• Be able to analyze real issues related to financial regulation
• Gain insight on current developments in financial regulation
courses.course_syllabus:
1. Fundamentals of the financial sector (interest rate and return, risks, information asymmetry etc).
2. Basic function and organization of central banks and other regulatory bodies.
3. Framework of banking and financial regulation (capital requirement, risk management and market discipline, the interactions between regulatory bodies and financial institutions)
4. Financial crises and their lessons
5. New developments in financial regulation (international cooperatiion, macro prudential policy, systemic risk regulatory authority etc)
courses.feedback_evaluation:
Course and teaching evaluation at end of course
Informal feedback channels throughout the course (face-to-face, email, WebCT)
Departmental Retreat
Programme Review
courses.required_readings:
1. Glenn Hubbard, Money, the Financial System and Economy, 6th Edition, Addison Wesley, 2007
2. Howard Davies and David Green, Global Financial Regulation, Polity, 2008
courses.recommended_readings:
1. Basel II: International Convergence of Capital Measurement and Capital Standards: A Revised Framework - Comprehensive Version, Bank of International Settlement, 2006
2. Macro-Prudential Regulation, World Bank, 2009

courses.subject: GLEF
courses.title: Internship Experience in Global Economics and Finance
courses.description:
Students are encouraged to explore opportunities of internship to fit their own specific learning needs. However, all self-selected internship must comply with the course requirements, and subject to the approval of GLEF Programme.

Students will be assessed by the course instructor afterwards.
courses.enrollment_requirement: Pre-requisite(s): at least 3 GLEF courses at 3000 or above level
courses.learning_outcomes: Students will be able to integrate theoretical knowledge and problem solving skills in a real world environment.
courses.course_syllabus:
Students are encouraged to explore opportunities of internship to fit their own specific learning needs. However, all self-selected internship must comply with the course requirements, and subject to the approval of GLEF Programme.

Students will be assessed by the course instructor afterwards.

courses.subject: GLEF
courses.title: Practicum in Global Economics and Finance
courses.description: This course provides students the opportunities to apply what they learned from the programme into action in a real world setting. Students are expected to carry out projects under the joint supervision of an instructor and an executive of the sponsoring company and submit a report by the end of the internship period.
courses.enrollment_requirement: Pre-requisite(s): at least 3 GLEF courses at 3000 or above level
courses.learning_outcomes: Students will be able to integrate theoretical knowledge and problem solving skills in a real world environment
courses.course_syllabus: This course provides students the opportunities to apply what they learned from the programme into action in a real world setting. Students are expected to carry out projects under the joint supervision of an instructor and an executive of the sponsoring company and submit a report by the end of the internship period.
courses.feedback_evaluation: The course will NOT employ the University’s Courses and Teaching Evaluation (CTE) as evaluation tool and reflection collected from individual student would be collated instead to see the effectiveness of the course in delivery of Learning outcomes.

courses.subject: GLEF
courses.title: Research Project on Global Economics and Finance
courses.description:
This course requires the student to conduct an individual research project on a topic in global economics and finance under the supervision of an instructor. The student is required to formulate a research topic, write a proposal, conduct literature search and review, compile datasets, carry out econometric analyses, write a final report, and present the findings in class.

Advisory: Course designed for students in their final year of major study in GLEF. Capacity limited. Priority given to students in their final year of major study in GLEF.
courses.enrollment_requirement: Pre-requisite(s): at least 3 GLEF courses at 3000 or above level
courses.learning_outcomes:
• To gain experience in conducting individual research under faculty guidance

• To improve in the ability to organize and present research findings in verbal and written form
courses.course_syllabus: The research topic is to be jointly developed by the student and the instructor. Any meaningful topic in global economics and finance is acceptable.
courses.feedback_evaluation:
• Course Evaluation at end of course
• Informal feedback channels throughout the course
• Programme Review
courses.required_readings: To be confirmed by the teacher.
